newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian PM says farms need state support - agency.
newsitem.headline: Russian PM says farms need state support - agency.

text.p: Russia should continue to subsidise the agricultural sector, Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin said on Thursday while on a tour of one of Russia's top grain-growing regions in southern Russia.
He said the sector, still cash-starved and struggling to raise enough credits, should receive as much budget money next year as this year.
"Our task is not to reduce 1997 levels (of financing the agricultural sector)," he was quoted by Interfax news agency as saying.

The government has tried to reduce farmers' dependence on Soviet-era state handouts, sharply reducing the level of cheap credits it was prepared to advance and encouraging farmers to work with commercial banks instead.
Just 2.7 trillion roubles ($465 million) were budgeted for the farm sector in 1997, a tiny fraction of the 16.1 trillion originally budgeted before the total was slashed.
Chernomyrdin said a draft tax code for 1998 would not wholly favour the development of agriculture.
"He said that this question in particular was discussed during his recent meeting with President Boris Yeltsin," Interfax reported.
Russia is overhauling its cumbersome tax structure, and the lower house of parliament State Duma began looking at the draft before the summer recess started.
"This problem must be solved during discussions on a tax code," Chernomyrdin said.
He said this year's grain harvest would be higher than in 1996, although not everything was going smoothly because the weather was not helping farmers gather the crops.
Late rains in key growing regions to the south of Russia have slowed the progress of the campaign, industry officials have said.
Agriculture Minister Viktor Khlystun forecast the 1997 net grain harvest at 80 million tonnes earlier this week, from 69.3 million in 1996.
